content:
Goal section
* Except for the quotation marks around "Big Two", you may remove all the other quotation marks. In general, you can remove the quotation marks around any text formatted as constants, unless it is unclear without the quotation marks.

* Suggest to format "rank" and "suit" in <<bold>>.

* Suggest to add

in the format "[[rank]][[suit]]"

after "13 cards".

Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The tests cases are robust, the description is clear and the puzzle is solvable in less than 5 minutes (only in the right language, probably).

I'm a bit uncertain about how will it fare in reverse mode, but it shouldn't be impossible.

After playing around a bit with the lists I was offering to my code, I found that this one passes every test but not every validator. The logic is obviously flawed, but since reverse is an option, it may throw off some solutions that can only rely on passing tests.

R = "34567891JKQA2"
S = "DCHS"
puts gets.split.sort_by{ [R.index(_1[0]), S.index(_1[1])] }*" "

The flaw is that Q > K. 

Atm it passes every test but not validator 2 and 4.

Maybe you could add a test for that?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: String manipulation and multi-conditional sort makes it interesting puzzle for the Clash of Code
Thanks for spotting this! I hate when I get 100% on tests and then fail validators. Swapping Validator 2 with Test 3 now.
I think it's always better to add a new testcase since swapping may possibly run into some other solutions passing all tests but not some validators.
Ok, I've added a new one now. Thanks.

Nice job on the new testpair, I found out that my previous (the one I thought to be correct, not the one I posted) solution which passed all testspairs now doesn't pass the last validator. It was:

R = "34567891JQKA2"
S = "DCHS"
puts gets.split.sort_by{ [R.index(_1[0]), S.index(_1[1])] }*" "

The reason is that I missed that we are comparing the second character in the second coordinate. So the 10H 10D part of the last validator, still becomes 10H 10D instead of the intended 10D 10H.

This is not tested in any public test, only in the last validator.

Maybe one more last testpair and we are set up ? :P

I've added another test pair that both fail for this mistake and I couldn't resist but just flip the order of the 10's suits in Test 4 so that it now fails this too.
I hate when edge cases only show up on the last test case, because it's so easy to accidentally submit before you realise. Thanks for spotting this one, it's likely to come up a lot in-clash.
Since your moto is about golf, I wanted to let you know that I managed to reach 79 chars (with pretty much the same solution as above). Tell me if you find better!
Ooh nice. :) I make a rule to not golf my own code until I get it in a shortest clash, so then I don't get too many extra advantages. Will keep this in mind for when I get it though.
